#Text=Santa Cruz ( Galapagos )
#Text=Santa Cruz is the most important ( although not the largest ) island in the Galapagos Islands archipelago , in Ecuador .

#Text=It contains the largest town in the Galapagos Islands , Puerto Ayora , which is the only location on the island with tourist infrastructure , on the southern side of the island , and is connected by road and ferry to the airport on Baltra Island .
#Text=It is also home to the Galapagos National Park administration , the Darwin Foundation , and the Charles Darwin Research Station .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Due to the central location of Santa Cruz in the archipelago , Puerto Ayora makes the best base for those wishing to visit the Galapagos while staying onshore .
#Text=Although it is a small town , it has the best infrastructure in the Galapagos with the largest number of hotels and restaurants , as well as shopping and supplies .
#Text=Services include include grocery stores , pharmacies , hardware stores , boat supplies , a small hospital and a hyperbaric chamber .
#Text=History
#Text=European and American interest in the Galapagos was stimulated by the publication of William Beebe 's book Galapagos : World 's End in 1924 .
#Text=This book inspired the beginnings of the eco-tourism that today dominates the Galapagos economy .
#Text=Tourism began , however , as only a trickle ( one of those early tourists was U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt , who visited the islands in 1938 ) .
#Text=There was also a trickle of Europeans immigration to the Galapagos around this time .
#Text=The largest group was 60 Norwegians , persuaded to settle on Floreana in 1927 by several young journalists and a whaler who had written about the Galapagos .
#Text=Floreana turned out to be anything but the paradise the promoters promised , as the colonists came to realize after the promoters left .
#Text=Most managed to survive for a difficult year or two there .

#Text=Some of the survivors eventually returned to Norway , others moved to the settlement on San Cristobal , and others settled on Academy Bay on Santa Cruz , joining another group of Norwegians that had set up a cannery there the year before .
#Text=Within a few years , most of the colonists left as well , but a few remained .
#Text=A few years later , other Norwegians came to Santa Cruz , as well as a sprinkling of others from Europe , America , and Ecuador , all seeking a simpler life .
#Text=Among them were the four Angermeyer brothers from Germany , who settled on Santa Cruz in 1935 .
#Text=Their descendants still live there and operate touring yachts and a hotel in Puerto Ayora .
#Text=Towns
#Text=The island is administrated as a single municipality , but contains several towns :
#Text=- largest town in on the island and the only one with major tourist accommodation
#Text=- at the center of the island
#Text=- near Puerto Ayora
#Text=- very small
#Text=By plane
#Text=Access to Santa Cruz is almost exclusively by air , with planes landing at the on the small nearby island of Baltra .

#Text=Inter-island flights are available from EMETEBE Airlines , which operates nine seater aircraft to transport passengers and their luggage from San Cristobal Airport to Isabela , Santa Cruz and Baltra islands .
#Text=Bookings can be done directly through EMETEBE 's website or a travel agent .
#Text=As of Nov 2018 , upon exiting the Baltra airport , board a bus to the Itabaca channel for $ 5 .
#Text=Proceed on a ferry/a smaller water taxi for $ 1 .
#Text=At the other end of the canal you can ride the bus into town ( $ 5 ) or take a taxi ( $ 25 ) .
#Text=For the reverse direction , buses from Puerto Ayora to the channel only leave in the morning .
#Text=Times may vary .
#Text=Check locally at the time ( at least a day before your flight ) .
#Text=If you have an afternoon flight , you 'll have to take a taxi ( $ 25 ) or find alternative transport .
#Text=By boat
#Text=There is public transportation via local speed boats to both San Cristobal and Puerto Villamil on Isabela daily .
#Text=They leave at 2PM and the 2-hour , and tend to be rough and noisy ( US$ 25 - 35 ) .
#Text=There are no bathrooms or other services available on these boats and passengers should carry their own water or snacks .
#Text=Private Yacht
#Text=Many people arrive annually by private yacht as part of a trip around the world .
#Text=Puerto Ayora and Puerto Baquerizo Moreno are the main ports of entry in the Galapagos - however most sail boats will enter at Puerto Villamil .
#Text=Boating in the Galapagos is restricted .
#Text=A non-Ecuadorian vessel arriving from a non-Ecuadorian port may stay up to 20 days in a single port .
#Text=Arrival fees are approximately $ 130 plus $ 3 per tonne for the vessel , plus $ 110 per person for the Park 's pass and island immigration .
#Text=National Immigration and Customs are about another $ 50 .

#Text=A permit to visit the five ports in the Galapagos ( Puerto Ayora , Baltra , Puerto Baquerizo Moreno , Puerto Villamil and Puerto Velasco Ibarra ) can be obtained by applying in advance with a ship 's agent .
#Text=These permits cost $ 300 for the vessel , in addition to the fees above .
#Text=This permit is the only way for an Ecuadorian vessel or a vessel arriving from mainland Ecuador to visit the Galapagos .
#Text=Licensed Yacht Handling Agencies can assist private vessels secure cruise permits .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The only paved road on the island is between the Itabaca channel and Puerto Ayora .
#Text=Busses will transport airport passengers from the ferry to Puerto Ayora and back .
#Text=There are also white pick-up trucks functioning as collectivo , just wait at one of the parades but they usually wo n't go further than Santa Rosa .
#Text=They also double as taxi
#Text=Puerto Ayora itself is small enough to explore by foot .
#Text=Most tourism is concentrated along the waterfront .
#Text=White pickup truck taxis operate and can provide transportation around town , into the highlands , or across the island .
#Text=Water taxis are available at the main dock and can take you to either a waiting boat or the dock on the other side .
#Text=In/around Puerto Ayora
#Text=Charles Darwin Research Station , Avenida Charles Darwin ( Located at the end of the road on the eastern edge of town ) .
#Text=6AM to 6PM M - Sa .
#Text=1.5 km west of the centre of Puerto Ayora .
#Text=It has a turtle breeding area and interesting information about the conservation of the unique biosphere of the Galapagos , and extensive exhibits on the natural history of the islands .
#Text=The breeding programs at the station allow visitors to see many iguanas , tortoises , and other animals in various stages of their lives .
#Text=Until his death in 2012 the station was also home to Lonesome George , a tortoise found on Pinta island who was believed to be the last of his sub-species .
#Text=George became a symbol of the park and for many years was known as the rarest creature in the world .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Tortuga Bay .
#Text=6AM-6:30PM daily .
#Text=a 2.5 kilometer long trail from Puerto Ayora leads to this beautiful beach with a strong undertow .
#Text=If you walk about 1 km further down the beach you reach a calm bay known as Playa Mansa .
#Text=The visibility in the water is n't perfect , but close to the mangroves
#Text=white tip sharks can be seen .
#Text=Marine turtles , pelicans , and Blue Heron sightings are also common .
#Text=Visitors must register at a at the beginning of the trail .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Punta Estrada beach/German beach .
#Text=small beach good for snorkeling especially with high tide .
#Text=Take a watertaxi ( $ 0.60 ) from Puerto Ayora to the Hotel Finch dock .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Las Grietas .
#Text=further up the trail from Punta Estrada beach following the green and white posts .
#Text=A spectacular canyon filled with crystal clear water .
#Text=Good for snorkeling .
#Text=A local swimming hole made from a large crevice between volcanic rock .
#Text=The water is clear and emerald green .
#Text=You can snorkel here but there is n't much to see besides a few large fish , probably as the water is a mix of the sea water and filtered rain water .
#Text=Taking a snorkel is worth it as there is a series of tunnels created by fallen rocks .
#Text=There are three swimming pools .
#Text=In the furthest you can climb up the rocks and jump down into the water .
#Text=Getting here .
#Text=From Puerto Ayora pier , hail over a yellow water taxi and tell them you want to go to Las Grietas .
#Text=$ 0.80 ( Nov 2018 ) will get you a one way trip and drop you off at Angermeyer Waterfront Inn .
#Text=Follow the well marked path through the iguanas , German 's beach , the salt pans , and the lava rock path to Las Grietas .
#Text=Along the path is a detour to the left .
#Text=Well worth the short walk to look down at the crystal clear water and the length of Las Grietas .
#Text=Closes at 5pm .
#Text=Getting away .
#Text=Back at the pier hail over a water taxi that 's waiting not to far from the pier .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Laguna Las Ninfas .
#Text=A pretty lagune with a footpath .
#Text=Free .
